lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a story and identify key characters and toys mentioned.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Before the story, preview toys in the SB. Say: “Listen for skateboard, football…” Students raise hands when they hear the word.
stretchStrategies: ❝Change-the-Story❞ – After acting out the story, ask students to imagine a new toy or location. They say or draw how the story would change (e.g., “He’s got a scooter at the zoo!”).

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read the story aloud, act it out, and answer questions using the target language.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Read the story aloud and pause after each sentence. Students echo with gestures. Assign roles for pair acting.
stretchStrategies: ❝Change-the-Story❞ – After acting out the story, ask students to imagine a new toy or location. They say or draw how the story would change (e.g., “He’s got a scooter at the zoo!”).

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can create a simple, imaginative ending to the story by drawing or acting it out.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Creativity) Ask: “What happens after the story?” Students draw or mime a new ending using known characters.
stretchStrategies: ❝Change-the-Story❞ – After acting out the story, ask students to imagine a new toy or location. They say or draw how the story would change (e.g., “He’s got a scooter at the zoo!”).

Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
